title: In NCAA v. Alston, will the Supreme Court rule that NCAA rules restricting education-related benefits for student-athletes violate federal antitrust law?
preds: Small change downwards because time is running out.
I'm still not convinced the Court will directly address the question, but following the crowd upward.
Increasing to reflect crowd-forecast. Tilting for Yes and time is running out.

Legislation Introduced Seeking to Provide Collective Bargaining Rights to College Athletes
May 27, 2021
https://www.si.com/college/2021/05/27/legislation-introduced-collective-bargaining-rights-college-athletes-bernie-sanders

Left and right leaning justices seemed ready to affirm for different reasons.  Justices did not seem to mind making a decision based on rule of reason, and the floodgates argument did not seem to have real traction during oral argument.  Desire to protect college sports only goes so far, when the issue is limited to education related benefits.  Some discounting for general base rate for reversals and possibility of a non-merits decision, but not much.

20-512 ("education-related benefits") may not be adressed in a split case, since the original NCAA v Alston case was about "eligibility rules regarding compensation of student-athletes [that may] violate federal antitrust law." (20-520(?)), according to the ISSUE statement of SCOTUSblog.

The Alston Oral Arguments: A Citations-Focused Perspective - Above the Law

It seems to be going this way, but I'm not confident
"Our antitrust laws were originally meant to prohibit exactly this sort of distortion"
Going with my gut initially. Planning to revisit this after I do some additional research.
Sure does! As long as the governements refuse to provide public money to those entities, at that point is a chicken and egg legal situation.

The Ninth Circuit was definitive, and both conservative and liberal justices challenged the NCAA assertions, albeit from different ideological points of view. Breyer wants to continue shamateurism for sentimental reasons, but that's not enough in the light of harsher and more rigorous legal and economic analysis. One could imagine a ruling limited to the revenue sports based on an economic pretext, leaving the field hockey, water polo, gymnastics, etc teams under the older more conventional scholarship regime

The likelihood of both being ruled and ruled positively looks to to be not that high. I had the prior that it was more likely than it wasn't but I'm not confident enough on this topic to go that against the crowd. Moreover, the antitrust law rationale looks rather strong + https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/31/supreme-court-appears-to-favor-college-athletes-in-ncaa-pay-case.html
After reading some of the analysis and reactions to the oral arguments, I am much more yes than no.

Adjusting to 'yes'. Statements from some of the most "conservative" judges on the bench suggest distaste for the NCAAs current treatment of players. I have a feeling that we may not see a ruling on formal payment, but in its place certainly a ruling on the educational-benefits will come.

I think the decision is going to skirt the question. As amateur athletes are not employees, anti-trust's hiring and compensation rules don't apply. As there is no price fixing on the product being offered (watching games), there is no basis for public harm. The issue that seems to have traction with the justices seems more a question of the fair labor standards act, which is not the issue at hand. I have a feeling that the Court will side with the athletes without addressing this question's particular issue of law.

In oral arguments (https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument_transcripts/2020/20-512_g314.pdf ) many judges were quite dismissive of the NCAA position on amateurism and its importance. One justice came very close to the joke about a prostitute just arguing about the price. Since this came from all parts of the court, it seems powerful - particularly Barrett’s question about why the NCAA gets to define what compensation is.  On the other side, judges were concerned about creating a narrow specific ruling that would have reverberating effects on future litigation. This suggests that they may rule against the NCAA with no explanation or opinion.

Oral arguments held 31/03 https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument_transcripts/2020/20-512_g314.pdf Docket history https://www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?filename=/docket/docketfiles/html/public/20-512.html Can’t find any indication of what comes next. As case is related to caps on education benefits, and it’s about college American football then it feels to a layman like me that it’s unreasonable to cap college student benefits and that it’s likely to be granted.

Treating YES as the solid case. Further reasoning:
1. Kagan and Kavanaugh seem to indicate their support to the athletes' arguments (according to other forecasters' judgements). Kagan and Kavanaugh agree with the consensus more often than the other Justices - that is other than Roberts.
2. Roberts seems to disagree with Kagan and Kavanaugh, but since Gorsuch seems to agree with Kagan and Kavanaugh it leans more YES. Why? Because last term whenever Roberts went against the consensus on only two occasions, Gorsuch disagreed on both occasions.
3. Because Sotomayor and Thomas, who normally disagree, are seemingly in agreement, it leans more YES.

https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/31/supreme-court-appears-to-favor-college-athletes-in-ncaa-pay-case.html
"Several of the court's conservatives expressed concerns that the NCAA's arguments are hypocritical or exploitative."
The only evidence regarding the position of the Supreme Court seems to be this. It indicates Alito, Kavanaugh, Thomas, and ACB are tilting against the NCAA and Roberts for it. The remaining judges are not mentioned.
I'm not an expert of anti-trust laws, but common sense isn't in the NCAAs favor, and the comments coming from the Supreme Court justices thus far don't seem very favorable to the NCAA.

increasing my estimate.
@Kerry-Hubers gives an interesting take on base rate that indicates overturning (no for the question) is more likely based on past similar cases being overturned. but I'm not convinced that base rate is the only relevant one since I don't know if all NCAA cases go through the 9th circuit. and the topic of the case might be a more relevant base rate than the circuit court it came from. it is the most clearly argued no estimate I've seen and it is still 55% for yes... @slapthepancake gives a justice by justice assessment of oral arguments that points heavily toward not overturning (yes for the question)  I tend to agree with this analysis. I did not read the arguments in anything like this depth, but my general takeaway from a quick skim was that both liberal and conservative justices were in agreement with the lower court but for different reasons.
The conservative justices don't seem persuaded by the NCAA arguments.  I think this case will end up 2-7
After reading @Kerry-Hubers and @slapthepancake, this outcome seems very likely.
Increasing chances after reading more detailed summary of oral arguments and another superforecasters' assessment Justice by Justice.

The Supreme Court reverses most decision with respect to which it grants cert.  The 9th Circuit is reversed 75% of the time.  This weighs heavily in favor of "No."  The summary of oral arguments indicates lots of animosity by Justices towards the NCAA exploitation of college athletes.  There are factors consistent with both conservative ideology (free market, freedom of contract, etc.) and liberal ideology (protecting the relatively powerless from exploitation, concern for racial/ethnic minorities who are disproportionately represented among high-revenue generating college sports compared to student bodies as a whole) that could get Justices from both sides on board a decision in favor of the student-athletes.  The Justices are very concerned about becoming perpetual referees for what restrictions are allowed and what aren't.  Most objective factors weigh against the question.  I evaluate the oral arguments as being in favor of upholding the 9th Circuit, but perhaps with some limiting principles.
The NCAA is on a major losing streak.

Oral Arguments Update It seems even more likely that the court will uphold the lower courts’ ruling after today’s oral arguments. I summarize briefly the types of questions/concerns that each judge had below, along with a probability of ruling against the NCAA for someone who spoke like that (ignoring the judge’s actual history, I already assessed outside rates previously). I think the main takeaway is that Sotomayor, Kagan, Gorsuch, and Kavanaugh are pretty sure yeses, and all of the other judges have at least a decent chance of joining them, especially Alito and Thomas. Barrett’s tough to judge, and Roberts and Breyer seem legitimately torn over implications for future pro-competitive joint ventures, while the rest are more focused on this case.  Roberts: 55% - it’d be odd to strike this down in favor of quick look, and there are payments made to players already. This individual rule being struck is modest but the principle isn’t, this may set precedent that the court can substitute its own view for the business judgments of a joint venture that’s been upheld as pro-competitive, and judges aren’t necessarily good for that. There’s also the concern about each individual rule being struck until the NCAA collapses like a Jenga tower.
Thomas: 85% - How do we preserve amateurism without constant litigation, what would the future challenges look like? How do we preempt them in considering this case? His tone was also pretty suggestive as a side note, like “how do we resolve that part of future problems that I see down the road.”
Breyer: 40% - Courts aren’t a good vessel for assessing LRAs for a joint venture when there’s a non-economic objective, it’s hard to account for administrative issues and to assess each mini-rule against consumer demand, and saying courts can determine that can be harmful to joint ventures in the future. Can avoid that by granting quick look, but that would be concerning for future economic joint ventures. 
Alito: 80% They are paid already, so it’s hard to justify a rule like this, but what’s the outer limit of what would be allowed by affirming this case? 
Sotomayor: 93% The injunction guards against your parade of horribles, and a narrow ruling is all that’s being requested here, so broader questions aren’t what’s being directly asked. Roberts’s Jenga argument is worrying though. 
Kagan: 90% - Can’t lean on the history forever, and the lower court’s analysis was that consumers didn’t care about this issue. Question is how do we not open the floodgates, and how do we make sure we aren’t price-administering per the arbitrary-seeming $5980 limit. She also denied a stay of the ban from the lower court. 
Gorsuch: 95% - Light scrutiny is usually given to joint ventures in a competitive market, but NCAA is the market, the monopsony justifies the increased scrutiny given. 
Kavanaugh: 95% - Qualitatively this is bad, its exploitative and the justification is disproven and outdated and disturbing. Need to find out what the end game is based on the ruling the court will give. 
Barrett: 50% - Hard to tell if she was asking leading questions or not. Concerned about women in sports, asked about who gets to define amateurism which is at the heart of the NCAA’s argument against the survey evidence, and seemed to suggest the cross-market balancing is distorting the court’s discussion. Didn’t seem to have a central concern.

Public opinion seems to favor allowing college athletes to earn professional fees and other financial benefits, including education-based benefits. The current conservative court will lean in favor of less restrictions.
The comments and questions from the conservative justices during oral arguments were more sympathetic to the athletes than I had expected.

I haven't read through all the oral arguments just some recaps so its possible I'm missing something important. however, it seems likely that the court will issue a ruling before July and that the ruling will be about the anti-trust issue and not some other nuance of the case. https://www.espn.com/college-sports/story/_/id/31172473/supreme-court-questions-validity-amateurism-ncaa-business-model
Given that, I think it is relatively harder to argue that the NCAA is not a monopoly controlling student athlete compensation. Seems like many of the justices both conservative and liberal seem to agree on that.  
If someone who has taken the time to read the actual arguments thinks I've got it wrong I'd love to hear your thoughts.
Kavanaugh comments today indicate a more likely ruling than I would have expected, but I still think it’s more likely they rule in favor of the NCAA

Change: +34 Reasoning: Justices today were very skeptical of everything said: https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/2021/03/31/supreme-court-grills-ncaa-compensation-case/4821059001/. Basically my theory for viewing this case is going out the door. I thought it was going to fall on partisan lines based around anti-trust but instead, we have the conservative justices questioning the application of anti-trust and liberals such as Breyer and Kagan worrying about the future of college sports. The justices by and large seem to think the NCAA's arguments are bad but are worried about what their ruling will bring. I will need to think about this before I make a more aggressive prediction.
Upping from 92 to 100 because court agrees with me.

"The upheld decision went into effect in August 2020, though the NCAA had sought an emergency request to hold the injunction prior to that. The NCAA along with the American Athletic Conference filed petitions to the Supreme Court in October 2020 to hear their appeal. Both asked the Court to review the Ninth Circuit's decision, arguing that the decision created a new definition of items that could be "related to education" which could be abused by colleges and sponsors to create effective "pay for play" programs in all but name, such as a hypothetical US$500,000-a-semester "internship" with Nike that the NCAA described as 'the antithesis of amateurism' ".
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association_v._Alston Several facts make me think this question is likely to resolve "No.":
/the appeal is also supported by the American Athletic Conference
/the original question of the appeal centers not so much about the constitutionality of the caps but more about the possible abuse of language and terms with respect to "pay to play" payments, and the alleged evasion of controls by athletes, their associations, colleges and corporate sponsors. Any ruling will first and foremost deal with the question, whether an "internship" is a contract with "pay to play" aspects.
/USD 500,000-a-semester "internships" are likely too much of a benefit to be justified as education-related and create lopside that has nothing to do with college sports any more, which will be hard to ignore for the SCOTUS judges. I guess the 2019 college admissions bribery scandal proved that success in an academic career depended for too long on wealth and money and influence (of the parents) and talent used to be underrated
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_college_admissions_bribery_scandal

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felicity_Huffman
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Buckingham
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lori_Loughlin People were sentenced to jail for much lesser sums than the 500,000USD in question, which proves that the inequalities in opportunity a 500,000USD "internship" would create would be material. Uncovering the bribery scheme and the following public scandal may give a spin to the NCAA v Alston case that SCOTUS likely is not able to ignore.
https://www.insider.com/college-admissions-scandal-full-list-people-sentenced-2019-9 (Water polo must be an exciting sport.)
This is probably overconfident, but I'm just going with the fact it's been going on for ages without being struck down and the right-wing lean of the court.

As Dylan sang, "The Times they are a Changin'." Wheras courts seemed to have more sympathy for the NCAA's anti trust arguments in the past, today's they seemingly have less stomach for the NCAA's pleas of keeping amateurism for amateurism's sake and that college football ceasing to exist without amateurism, especially as their revenues continue to climb ever upwards. The fact is that the courts have traditionally rejected antitrust arguments centering on social goals and there is no evidence to support the idea that college football cannot continue on in its current form if the players are paid.

Change: -12 Reasoning: I'm starting to get very certain not only that this court will be ideologically hostile to excepting the 9th circuit's anti-trust logic but also starting to wonder if the 9th circuit's decision is radically out of step with the country. After reviewing the amicus briefs filed for and against the case I found not one petitioner in support of applying the 9th circuit's anti-trust logic. The petitioners asking for the supreme court to reverse the 9th circuit decision are as follows:
- NCAA (not shocking)
- The attorney generals of GEORGIA, ALABAMA, ARKANSAS, MISSISSIPPI, MONTANA, NORTH DAKOTA, SOUTH CAROLINA, AND SOUTH DAKOTA
- A group of anti-trust economists
- A group 10 associations that promote high school sports
- A group of former NCAA athletes who worry what salaries would do to NCAA sports
- Anti-trust professor Thomas B. Nachbar While I suspect some of these briefs were filed after the NCAA's law firm tried to search for briefs, this is something that I will need to investigate further, its a very strong signal that not ONE brief was filled in support of the 9th circuit's ruling.
Things have been moving in this direction for some time and this is the next logical step.

This is a pretty hard call because the outside and inside views pretty sharply conflict with each other. From the outside view, as @Jibreel_PCV has explained well, is pretty dismal, the Court rules against 9th circuit rulings quite often, and rulings in favor of antitrust defendants have been much more common in the past few decades (https://www.clearygottlieb.com/-/media/organize-archive/cgsh/files/publication-pdfs/antitrust-decisions-of-the-us-supreme-court.pdf). Outside rate would be something like 10-15% for this case.  Even anchored on that as the base rate, I still put a pretty high probability on the Court ruling against the NCAA, largely due to the facts of the case and recent trends in Supreme Court jurisprudence in antitrust cases. Firstly, the court denied a request to stay the ruling against the NCAA, though the denial was done by Kagan who skews liberal. They also denied cert to and effectively upheld a similar previous case from 2015 (O'Bannon vs. NCAA) regarding athletes' NIL rights. While it’s possible that the Court would've denied cert to this case if they supported the plaintiff in the same way they did O'Bannon (and granting cert indicates intention to rule differently), I think that their history with O'Bannon bodes well for this case.  The most important thing to consider is trends in Supreme Court antitrust jurisprudence. The most helpful article in this regard is from the law firm Ropes and Gray (https://www.ropesgray.com/-/media/Files/articles/2014/July/Summer14-PopofskyC.pdf?la=en&hash=3B6CDB12F8F459A9EFCEEB08BC76A4E4C79E5008), though it is from 2014. The first trend is the court's movement away from specialized antitrust rules and taking nuanced views of antitrust exceptions, usually in favor of Rule of Reason analyses. As background, certain practices like price fixing are explicitly illegal per antitrust statutes, however, a court can allow the practice if it is situationally procompetitive and not overly restrictive. The Rule of Reason is a specific test that the court can use to see if an action is procompetitive and should be allowed. The NCAA openly engages in horizontal price fixing via compensation caps, but they argue that it is pro-competitive because lack of compensation (and students competing for love of the game) is necessary to differentiate college sports from pro sports. Having two different categories increases consumer choice and promotes competition. Alston is arguing that capping education-related compensation is overly restrictive, and it doesn’t help differentiate college sports from pro sports. The Court moving away from specialized treatment of exceptions is obviously very important in this case, as the NCAA is leaning on the presumption that NCAA rules preserving amateurism are permissible under antitrust law, as written in the Court's decision in NCAA vs. Board of Regents of University of Oklahoma. A movement away from that type of thinking and towards an explicit preference by the Court for applying the Rule of Reason to each case that comes before the court would make this case far riskier for the NCAA. Most of that risk in this case is because NCAA's evidence used in their Rule of Reason argument is frankly pretty bad, and Alston's distinctly better. The details from the appeals court's decision is here on page 39 (https://www.supremecourt.gov/DocketPDF/20/20A24/149461/20200805105637321_Attachment%201%20-%20Alston-Ninth%20Circuit%20merits%20opinion%205-18-2020.pdf). Arguing that education-related benefits caps aren't justified or necessary for preserving demand for college sports isn't a big jump, and the evidence presented by Alston in this case was persuasive, while the NCAA's was quite weak. The NCAA's arguments for their caps are usually to the effect of "we need to prevent unlimited pay, akin to sports salaries", which is quite a leap from the education-related caps being argued which can't even be paid in cash. The last significant change is a willingness by the Court to allow unsettled issues in applying the rule of reason to percolate down to the lower courts. The case against the NCAA sounds quite strong, and a willingness to let unsettled issues percolate down in this case may indicate a willingness by the court to issue a ruling on this case to set the precedent that NCAA rules are subject to the Rule of Reason and get rid of the sentiment expressed back in Regents, and then let future decisions be decided by lower courts within that framework.  There are a few points of uncertainty here though. The first is that there are 3 fairly new judges on the bench, all appointed after the mentioned article, so there's no guarantee that the changes in jurisprudence will continue. Antitrust cases, especially ones relevant here, aren't super common, so the new justices' opinions are hard to gauge. Secondly, a lot of the details of this case are being read through documents produced by the lower courts that issued rulings against the NCAA, meaning there's likely a bias in most of the information that's presented about the case and the relevant legal issues. The evidence presented in the appeals court document cited before is structured around the ruling that was eventually issued, specifically including information that explained the final decision, so it's possible that some information was left out or presented in a skewed way. Thirdly, I'm not a lawyer or law student. I'm more vulnerable to unrecognized biases in what I read, and I don't know what I don't know about this case. The court may have options for treating this case that I don't know exist that I'm not factoring into my Yes probability. Overall, abysmal outside rate, but quite a compelling yes case based on details of the case, though uncertainty remains.

Raising to account for news that the NCAA does concede that education and "amateurism" are not necessarily valid excuses to violate antitrust law. Therefore, the Justices have will further hone in on the question at hand.
Yes. I think the walls are closing in on the NCAA.

I had misinterpreted the question once again. My re-analysis on historical cases where both lower courts agree and Supreme Court takes case favor NO. Most times, (1) petitioner wins and most times (2) a 9th Circuit opinion is reversed. So far four base rates (these two plus the overall petitioner win ratio and the GJO "bias" toward NO resolution) indicate that the NCAA will win their case at the Supreme Court. However, these are not necessarily causal mechanisms interplaying.

1. It appears a significant portion of incumbent court cases into the Supreme Court, initiating action, where other courts have agreed, have a higher win ratio.  2. Conservatives are majority on Supreme Court, generally against pay cap’s or minimums in current economic society.  3. After some review, NCAA does appear to be a monopolistic organization with extensive control over the industry.  4. The court may recognize other option exists for college players to achieve their economic goals, relative to their skill.  Makes sense the court would confirm prior rulings. Among many caveats, sometimes court rulings are fairly vague and it is difficult to determine who won.

Change: -10. I've adjusted my base rate with some data from scotus blog. 70% of cases from the 9th circuit have been reversed. I'm going to adjust once I check the current Supreme Court justices views on anti-trust https://ballotpedia.org/SCOTUS_case_reversal_rates_(2007_-_Present.
I will need to be cautious until I know more

There is likely broad agreement that  certain schools/athletes could make a lot more money for themselves if not bound by current NCAA rules. But is the restraint unreasonable? As often noted, the NCAA, participating schools (and implicitly to athletes) have gained from increasing revenue streams, but the money-flow is spread over a variety of NCAA activities including lower-tier schools and sport categories. Though not a perfect sharing arrangement, what makes an BROAD anti-trust ruling result in a more perfect  financial distribution?  I fail to adequately grasp how court-room arguments focusing on whether certain athletes/schools will make more or less $$s gets to the central question of unfair constraint. In one of the references to this question, it is noted that the "Power Five" is potentially at odds with the NCAA and has contemplated a competing governance structure. Wouldn't this be an exercise of competition?  It may be that SCOTUS could be open to allowing some additional benefits to athletes/schools that expand current NCAA restraints, but it doesn't seem that current lower-court decisions have adequately differentiated the legal outlines in this case. SCOTUS could provide a ruling, that currently preserves current NCAA authority to create a hold on state-specific laws that jumble this matter, while lower courts are given guidance to clarify the the boundaries of the anti-trust question.

I'm leaning no because the Supreme Court traditionally takes cases from the 9th circuit to reverse them. However, I am not that confident because of the 3 judge panel on the 9th circuit that sided with the plaintiffs one of the justices that wrote the concurrence and agreed with the panel was Milan Smith, a moderate-conservative justice, who wrote that he was disturbed at the absence of "free-market" conditions. So it seems very probable that the court might uphold the decision. I just don't know why they would have taken it then.

About a 70% chance the Court rules in the petitioners' (NCAA's) favor. About a 70% chance Circuit decision for NCAA is reversed. 70% chance of NCAA winning its legal battles. 70% chance any question of GJO resolves in NO. 50% win-rate at Supreme Court for NCAA. Even keel up to this point. Now for 87% chance of reversal at the Ninth Circuit. This I will consider more of an inside view. I shall average 50 and 87 to arrive at 69%. Back around 70. My confidence remains because of the relatively stronger conservative court this time around, which should challenge the relatively "liberal" idealogies of the Ninth Circuit and its decision to rule in favor of the athletes in NCAA v. Alston. NOTE: This forecast might have an erroneous interpretation and may have confused certain arguments.

First forecast is gut feeling. I put probability at 50% I believe the supreme court will rule in favour of the student athletes ultimately, my hesitation is more in the timeline to come to a "yes" solution (term end date = Oct 3, 2021).

The question of law is "Whether the Sherman Act authorizes a court to subject the product-defining rules of a joint venture to full Rule of Reason review, and to hold hose rules unlawful if, in the court’s view, they are not the least re-strictive means that could have been used to accomplish their procompetitive goal."  It is not a question of ahould amateur athletes receive cost of education payments or should the NCAA have carte blanche antitrust immunity.  SCOTUS by denying review of Bannon has already indicated NCAA is a joint venture with unique rules but not anti-trust immunity.  
So should the trial court have done a"quick look" or a rule of reason review? That is question 1.  
Question 2 is if a quick look was not required then did the trial judge properly apply rule of reason to concujde the NCAA rules were not the least restrictive set of rules to apply to protect the amateur model?
This court is going to rule on the law and some of its own precedents.  Unlike baseball exemption created by the supreme court in 1920's there is no Stare Decisis to respect.  It passed in Banon.  It took this case probably because the new justices wanted it and I think they will uphold the ninth circuit and tell the NCAA to get Congress to grant them anti-trust immunity.
The question resolves yes if the opinion says the rules violate anti-trust. The possible outcomes are for the NCAA, for Alston, or sending it back to the ninth for further review. Do not discount that last one. It happens when they quickly grab a case and then realize the record is not fully developed.
I don't think the current make-up of the Supreme Court favors antitrust cases.

The us has a majority of republicans sitting. Republicans likey believe in student athletes making money. There has been some admissions scandles recently which could go the other way. But the morality of not accepting money for college athletics is from a time when college grads made more money from the social capital of mixing with the privileged. Now it's a market like any other.

Amateurism is an important, honorable, well-aged principle in sports, and competition.
Making caps obsolete by anti-trust argumentation will create new restrictions to equal and fair competition, compare "financial fair play" in general.
Furthermore, the rule-setting authority of sports associations in general, and the ability to arbitrate/settle disagreements within the authorities of the world sports, e.g. CAS
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport
seems to be an outstanding principle that the US Supreme Court will not want to topple for the business interest of a few individuals. I'm not sure the SCOTUS will deal with the lawsuit and its antitrust claims at all, since it seems to be a misfit/false claim in the absence of real argument.
The court will say the law does not address it and state that congress would have to amend the law to provide those protections.
